p: It is difficult to compare incidences and prevalences, because the case definitions used in different studies vary, and most studies reflect the endemic disease in industrialized countries [ 1]. Another contributing factor complicating agreement on incidence and prevalence is that encephalitis is, in most countries, not a notifiable disease [ 20]. Britton et al. (2016) mention incidence ranges of between 2.8 and 10.5 per 100,000 that have been reported in England, Sweden and the USA [ 21]. The highest rates have been documented in infants less than 1 year of age. Hospital admissions of children due to encephalitis decreased over a period of 11 years in Australia, but the average hospitalization rate was 5/100,000 [ 21]. There has been a significant decrease in varicella encephalitis, explained by good varicella vaccine coverage [ 21]. By contrast, an increase in ADEM-related encephalitis has been documented, and ADEM-related encephalitis now accounts for 15â€“17% of encephalitis-related admissions [ 21].
